We arrived late at night and in fact it was 3am UK time - the checkin was abrupt and unsympathetic.  There were no tea/coffee making facilities in the room - all this a luxury hotel!  What?!!  So on our first morning, we requested 2 x teas and 1 x coffee from room service - How much?  $40!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  An absolute joke!!  Bathroom small but functional.  We went down to the restaurant and chose to have the buffet - well, the worst buffet I have ever seen.  We do luxury hotel service so much better in the UK. Here, there was nothing more than stale bagels and luke warm 'hot' food every day!  The housekeeping staff were abrupt and got the hump when we went down for breakfast and twice came back into our room to find her on her phone, in our room!  She asked how long we would be before going out and then kept ringing on the door bell to find out when we were actually going!  As someone else said on their review, for the money you pay to stay there you would expect it to have stunningly perfect service but oh no!  If you're like us and expect to get what you pay for with regards to service then you're in the wrong place at The Marriott Essex House.  So, in summary, I would say: Extortionate, poor service, unfriendly, but great location... and we loved NYC and will be back but not to the Marriott Essex House.

title: Great location and character, comfortable, expensive, patchy service
text:
I'm a big fan of hotels that have a venerable history but have combined modern conveniences with the character that comes from those bygone days. Since the Essex House dates from the 1930s I understand, and has managed to achieve this balance well. 

We were here for a 3 night stay, 2 rooms. A stay here, like this, will cost you. There is no escaping that and for the amount of coin one drops here, the service had better be impeccable. More on this below. One of the benefits of an historic hotel, is that not all rooms are the same and judging by the two we had, this is certainly the case here. Rooms can be quirky but both of ours were very nice, comfortable and easy to spend time in. One of our rooms had a delightful, deep tub which is rare in US hotels in my experience and very welcome. Our second room had a shallower bath but still just enough to soak in but I wish hotels would put in a deep tub or else opt for a walk in shower over the shallow, over the tub shower option that seems standard in far too many places.

The bed was very comfortable, sheets clean and crisp. Obviously, although the hotel faces the park, not all the rooms do, so higher and front facing are obviously best but, I assume, the most expensive. I am not a fan of pressure sensitive minibars and those featured here. Come on. Really? I don't want to risk getting charged for something that I pick up to look at and then put back, only to miss it on my bill. At this level of hotel, at this price, this is bordering on the offensive.

One of the great benefits of being a Titanium member of Bonvoy, is access to the lounge which was major during this stay as we were able to partake of the excellent breakfast laid on there daily, and at no extra cost to us. This was well worth it and the lounge was spacious and well appointed. Too many TVs including one displaying the Fox propaganda service but I suppose one can't have everything.

The hotel is 44 floors and has a bank of elevators some of which serve floors 1-19, some 18-44 and the system works well although there are some differences in that one elevator seemed to allow access to all floors although that wasn't obvious until one was inside. The system is pretty secure, requiring a room key to proceed upstairs, and with a ubiquitous security guard quietly, and somewhat unsmilingly on duty at all times. Well done Essex for managing the elevators so that we never waited more than a minute or so at any time, either in the lobby or on our floor. This is an important facet that not all hotels pull off.

Now to the cons of the Essex which, in addition to the aforementioned minibar issue are infuriating at this level. Firstly, there is a $35 dollar per room, per night "destination fee". Nonsense. Outrageous. This is akin to seeing a "resort fee" on the bill. Honestly, what on Earth is that? Basically a "use it or lose it" fee that you can't stack so one is basically forced to spend $35 a day on room service, mini-bar etc or you will be charged it anyway. I HATE this practice. If you want to charge me more for the room, put it on the room rate and don't play these games. It's sharp practice of the worst kind, unworthy on Marriott and especially one of its premium brands. It caused a lot of heated discussion as guests were checking out.

Many of the staff were very friendly, especially those in housekeeping BUT on a number of occasions we had questions about potentially moving our rooms to be closer together (at least on the same floor), late checkout and luggage storage and the person on the end was brusque and unhelpful on more than one occasion to the point of rudeness. If this is how a hotel treats its guests with Bonvoy status I wonder what they do to others? I realize the pomposity and entitlement inherent in that statement but honestly a premium brand, at these prices, should do better. 

And that's the thing. This is a very nice hotel and it is an excellent base from which to explore NYC but these missteps, blamed with a shrug by the staff on "COVID" and "Staffing" issues should not happen at this price. I've had better customer service from hotels charging me $129 a night and trust me, the Essex is way, way, north of that in price. It didn't particularly translate to that in terms of service on this visit and that's a shame. Will I stay here again? Probably not. I think there are better options in the City.

title: Beautiful Spring Weekend
text: It was a busy week for Essex House but they pulled all the stops to make sure my husband had a fabulous birthday. We were upgraded to a deluxe suite overlooking Central Park.  Our little family enjoyed playing hide and seek, trying to get fancy people to wave at us from 5th Avenue from our window and marveling at the heatless option of our fireplace (we are from Vermont).  The city was a ablush with spring blooms and happy people- but we we’re definitely the happiest.  Thank you so much for making this birthday so special.

title: Fantastic place to stay!
text: This was the best hotel! What a wonderful location and experience. I asked for a sofa for our daughter who lives in NYC to stay a night or two through their chat a few days before. Even though they were sold out, they made sure we had a sofa and pull out bed for a couple of nights. It really made that extra special. The room was very spacious. One night they even left us a bottle of wine and a tray of chocolates. I asked if it was a mistake, and they said it was just for us to enjoy. We will definitely stay there again!

title: Wonderful Stay in NYC
text: This was our first trip back to NYC in two years and the Essex House made our return to NYC and Easter celebration with family extra special!  The staff is wonderful, the rooms are spacious and comfortable, and the location adjacent to Central Park is perfect.  Cannot wait to return!  An absolutely wonderful place to stay!

title: Good property but they scam you on the parking
text: This is a nice property given the location, but as mentioned previously in another review they scam you on the parking and charge your valet as oversized and hope you don't notice. We drive a Toyota Prius and it was billed as oversize and wasn't told until we received the final bill a week later. Plenty of back and forth and it's still unclear when my refund will be received. Very sketchy behavior and when you're paying $500++ a night you deserve better than this.

title: Never booking at another Marriott again.
text:
TLDR: They were overbooked and gave me an inferior room while attempting to charge me the price of Junior Suite until I complained about it, took 2 days to give me the actual room I wanted, Cockroach on bed, back to inferior room, left the hotel and went to another hotel.

Type of room booked: Junior Suite
Length of stay: Supposed to be 7 days
Price Quoted: ~$5,265.08

CHECK IN: I arrived to check-in at the hotel at night after a long flight for my anniversary trip to NYC. There was a small line and one person at the Front Desk. After a few minutes I was checked into my room and notified that they needed to charge my card instantly (prepay) because they would be changing the computer system. I agreed, no big deal I had to pay that amount regardless. Service was acceptable, nothing fancy.

ARRIVE AT 1ST ROOM: We were escorted to our room by a bellboy who pushed our single bag, he wasn't very talkative although he did answer our question of when the hotel was built. As soon as I saw the room I questioned whether this was a Junior Suite. The room looked like a regular king bed room with a small desk. After a $10 tip I asked the bellboy if this was a suite, he replied "yes" and promptly left the room. I was not convinced and went online to look for any pictures referencing the different types of rooms at the hotel and found that the room I was in one of the rooms of something they called a "Family Connector" which is basically a Regular King Room.

1ST COMPLAINT: I called the front desk several times with no answer so I decided to make my way down there. When I arrived I spoke to a different person than the one who checked me in. I showed them my reservation, which was done directly through the Marriott official website btw, and politely asked if there was some sort of mistake. The person at front desk told me they did not have any suites available and since I didn't want to cause problems at the beginning of my trip I said I wanted to be charged the appropriate amount for the room I was in and I asked to be changed to the correct room (Junior Suite) as soon as possible. I was told at front desk that this would happen in 2 days so I had to sleep in this room for two nights. I agreed and left. It's important to note that no apology nor courtesy was offered subsequent to this first event.

1st ROOM SERVICE: Back in my room with my wife, we wanted to order some in room dining; thus, called room service. When we asked for a menu, we were told they were about to close the kitchen and were given a few options to choose from. I found it kind of odd that a 5 star hotel wouldn't have 24hr room service but we ended up ordering two burgers and the rest of the night went without incident.

CONFIRMATION: The next morning I went to confirm that the room change was scheduled properly for the next day (can't ever be too careful after the wrong room incident). I was told by front desk (different staff now) that it said I would be offered a suite "If available". I explained the situation to the front desk person, I was told everything would be scheduled automatically and that I should leave my bags packed because they would take care of it. They did as promised.

JUNIOR SUITE: On the 3rd day, we arrived late to the hotel since we went to a Jazz Club, we asked for our new room keys and after a small back and forth and explanation were given our keys. We found our bags in the suite and everything seemed fine until we decided to take a bath after a long day. As soon as we opened the faucet to the bathtub Yellow Brown disgusting water came out, we let it run for a little while and decided to cancel the bath time.

2nd ROOM SERVICE: We then decided to order room service once again and no one picked up the phone for some time. Eventually someone picked up the phone but they just dialed some numbers and hung up. We decided to order Pizza.

COCKROACH: After the pizza arrived, we ate in the living room part of the suite, wife went to bed, turned off most lights and I followed her about 10 minutes later. When I moved the bed sheets to lay down I felt something sting my hand, I jerked away the sheet and saw a large cockroach crawling on it. I shaked the bed sheet to make it fall from it and killed with my shoe on the floor. (attaching picture)

2nd COMPLAINT: I called front desk multiple times until someone picked up. I asked to please talk to the manager on duty. I very calmly explained to the manager the situation from day 1 until this moment, I explained how this was not the experience I expected from a 5 star hotel I told her I really wanted to leave this hotel and asked what she would do in my case. She told me she wouldn't want to sleep in that bed and that she was sending me keys to a new room immediately. Since it was late already, I agreed.

3rd AND FINAL ROOM: We were moved to another room but it was once again a regular room not a suite. I decided to research a little and find somewhere else to go the next day.

CHECK OUT: The next morning we came down with our bags to check out before the 7 days we were supposed to stay there. I asked once again to speak to the manager on duty and explained once again the whole story which by now she seemed to have received some sort of note from the night manager.

I told her I wanted to check out and was planning to move to another hotel and asked if they could hold my large bag until I checked into a new hotel. She apologized for the experience and told me that "every night you didn't spend in the room you booked, I won't be charged for." to which I replied "that's every night" and she said: "Yes, your stay will be complimentary". Without further ado I moved to another hotel, which was amazing from the beginning and a true 5 star experience.

FINAL CHARGES: Even though I was told the stay would be complimentary by the last manager I spoke to, there seems to be a permanent charge in my card for a partial amount. I don't know if I will be reimbursed or not in the end for my whole stay,  but for now some charges are there though not all.

CONCLUSION:
1) I expect a proper apology and maybe some type of courtesy note from management to let me know they're sorry for this mistake. At least in a 5 star hotel in front of central park in Manhattan.
2) This is personal, but I have decided not to stay again at a Marriott property in the near future. This experience has shown me that their top management doesn't have top quality customer service in mind.
3) Even though the hotel managers resolved the issue at the moment and were very understanding and kind, I cannot recommend staying at this hotel to anyone because you run the risk of a similar situation happening to you and could ruin a potential vacation.

Sorry for the long review but it's a series of events that needed to be unfolded.

title: New York City is back!
text: I recommend room 1404 for a fantastic view of Central Park!  The reception desk staff and Concierge were extremely helpful, and check-in and check-out were very quick and easy.  The beds were extremely comfortable.  The rooms were very large for NYC.  The kitchen’s chef went table-to-table, asking guests about our stay.  The Essex is probably the most friendly of any hotel I’ve been to in the city.  I will return to the Essex on my next trip to NYC!

title: A NYC Gem!
text: We are just finishing up our 2nd stay here and will definitely be back. This is a beautiful art deco property just across from Central Park. The lobby is beautiful with plenty of lounge seating. The bar mixes a great Manhattan. The executive lounge has a great assortment of food and beverages. The staff was wonderful...friendly and accommodating. The standard king room is much larger than you find in many Manhattan hotels, nicely updated, with an awesome bed. Best of all it is nice and quiet - an oasis after you come home from the noise and craziness that make NYC wonderful. Would absolutely recommend!

title: Worst hotel experience. Overprice and poor service.
text:
Our four-nights stay was by far one of the the worst hotel experience. Only the bellboy was friendly and a God-sent. 
The front desk check-in lady was unfriendly and being difficult when we checked in.

The hotel is outdated and not well maintained (the paper wall is peeling off… blinds not working properly… a/c ventilation system creating loud noise so we had to leave it off during cold winter.) 

The strangest part is that the housekeeping would not update amenity in the room, and no water was provided (only plastic cups in the room. no minibar, nor coffee/tea provided in room.)

All in all, it’s truly a miracle that this hotel is still running. Definitely not worth the money.

Will choose a different hotel when we return to New York.

title: 5 stars all around.  An amazing experience at the Essex house.
text:
I truly loved my experience at the JW Marriott Essex House.  The staff are amazing, and have an obvious commitment to customer service, assisting in celebrating a special occasion!

The hotel is a beautiful art-deco structure, in a prime location on Central Park. It’s very close to Times Square, and subway stations.  
 The lobby was large and clean, with a throwback style, and helpful staff.  Check in was a breeze, with my bags being taken up to my room for us as our room wasn’t quite ready.  

We spent two nights in a Manhattan view suite, which was an amazing room.  The room was huge, with an amazing large terrace with great views of the Manhattan skyline, including some of the biggest buildings.   The living area included a separate sitting area, a desk, and a  large sectional couch.  The bathroom was large, spacious  and modern,  with a separate shower / soaker tub.  

The separate bedroom was also large, with a very comfortable bed, and great views.  We used the fitness centre twice, which had a great selection of equipment, including a peloton, and plenty of water!   The restaurant was fast, and tasted great, and although I felt maybe the drinks were a bit overpriced, the $35 daily credit offset it. Platinum status meant access to the lounge, and Breakfast there was plentiful, fresh and tasted great. 

All the staff were very friendly and genuinely interested in helping.  I left something down in the gym, and called to see if anyone turned it in, and within 2 minute it was at my door. 

I will definitely return, and in fact, won’t be staying anywhere else in Manhattan.

title: Great Stay at the JW Marriott Essex House in NYC
text:
We stayed from Wednesday to Friday and we enjoyed the hotel restaurant on Wednesday night and the tuna tartare, chicken and salmon were terrific!. Being Titanium Platinum, we had the lounge breakfast which had a nice variety of a selection. The staff at the front desk was exceptional along with the doorman, porter for luggage, car valet, and maid that cleaned our room.
The hotel is beautiful, and immaculately clean, and taking all Covid considerations.
We had a wonderful stay and plan to come back!
Thank you so much to everyone at JW Marriott Essex House!

title: Michael Antonelli
text:
I had a 3 night stay during new years. The stay was nice, not bad.

Prior to my stay I contacted Mr. Michael Antonelli, the concierge, who given me the best advises for my stay in all matters, which theatres to try, which transports to take, where to go for PCR testing, where to walk ... etc. This man was perfect in every way , and literally he was the best thing in my entire stay.

Room was small, which is expected in new york ( though it's a JW marriott ). But it was comfortable.

Location is unbeatable, close to the colombus circus and of course overlooking central park.

Sadly due to covid I wasn't able to try their room service as they were limited to certain hours.
Food at the lounge , where I had my breakfast , was very nice with lots of varieties and options.

I had an incident after check out which should be mentioned. I checked out at 8:30, went to the airport directly to catch my morning flight, during my flight however I contacted the hotel to get my bill, and when I received it I saw a breakfast charge  at the hotel after my check out time, literally was during my flight out of new york!! The matter was resolved and I was refunded back for that amount, but until now I find it extremely strange to happen, especially that during my entire stay I never had any meal or snack at the their restaurant/bar. I was told they would investigate the matter, but was never given an update.

If you are staying at the hotel, make sure you check every item on your bill.

title: Met expectations.
text:
If you want to be across from Central Park, then this is a good option. We went on Thanksgiving weekend, so it was nice that we could walk out of the hotel on the sidewalk and get a front row standing area along the parade route. Rooms were newly and nicely renovated. Efficiently packed all the things in a NYC size hotel room. Restaurant food was OK with NY prices. Lobby was class art deco, small, dark and needs a renovation. Service was excellent especially in the lounge. Even though lounge was packed, everybody in the lounge made it feel very personal.
For platinum/titanium: the breakfast option is the best I've had in the US. It is like breakfasts in Europe or Asia.

title: Nice Plat Upgrade
text: Stayed here one night for business. Got upgraded for being platinum to a junior suite which was lovely.   Rooms are very quiet with  nice finishings.    The location is fantastic, right across from Central Park and within walking distance to everything.  Ate dinner at the restaurant and meal was good and service attentive.   I would stay here again.

title: I am we are disappointed.
text:
Fantastic location next to THE Central Park.  Spectacular interior, hall, elevator.

THE ‘story”:

- We arrived very late at night, waiting for the transfer at JFK in vain. We asked the hotel to send a taxi for us, they did not send anyone, although they asked what extras we needed. No problem. Welcome!

- There was a beautiful snowfall, minus 2 Celsius, we were freezing a bit… we would like to have had a hot tea or hot soup in the hotel at arrival but were told there was no longer a CHEF in the kitchen.
Interesting answer... a hot tea could have been solved somehow.

- It was barely 20 degrees in the suite, no heating at all. The marble bath has no heating (neither technically and physically), the hot shower would heat you up.

- One of the curtain did not work. Never fixed.

- We asked for a private driver and guide for a sightseeing next day.  The driver was only a driver, no guiding, we thought it was a kind of 2 in 1. It wasn’t. He is only talking about how expensive the city is.
He took us twice along the river.  Where we asked him to take us, he did not want to go because there was a lot of traffic on the bridge and he could not park there.
After it turned out we understand HUGO's native language, he hung up the phone with “AMOR”.  He seemed to be offended, we should rather run away from that point. We only requested the service for 3 hours (that was the minimum ride), so another insult for him.  He decided not to talk at all, if/when he did, he was more unfriendly, almost aggressive.

We have made a feedback at the hotel about the SIGHTSEEING that we asked for BUT we were informed by the Concierge (who organised the tour) that we misunderstood her… the tour with a guide would have been more expensive. What? It was barely $ 90 for an hour.  The 3 hours still came out at $ 320.  Oh yeah, HUGO -originally from Columbia - was a real unintelligent one who hated his work, in the end he does not even say goodbye to us.
We thank you for the “wonderful” absolutely and definitely tourist scraper production.

- Returning back to the hotel in the evening, frozen again, decided to sit in the bar for a hot tea. After waiting 10 minutes at the table for someone to come and to at least great us (in vain of course),  went back to our room. The bar was overcrowded with a total of 3 people but the staff was far too busy to ask us what on earth we were sitting around.

We are THE  problem again.  Fckg European tourists!! They want to be served. Incredible. Even the idea. In a 5-star hotel ?? No way.

- Hotel cleanliness : There is no particular problem with except that my clean pajamas were put on the dirty suitcase after cleaning.  No worries.  Covid, virus, pandemic, quarantine… take it easy !

- Room service: perfect, polite. We drank a lots of hot tea with honey in the evenings.  The only one star I give is only for them.

Soooo sad because we have wonderful memories of the same hotel chain in Vienna, Europe.  There is no “we’re glad you’re here, we’re grateful you chose us” feeling here in New York.

Last night we got a farewell (means: thank you to leave finally and don’t bother us more) champagne and desserts that we couldn’t consume because we went for a covid test.

It is a shame because the organization of the trip itself and the whole paperwork is very complicated and expensive due to the covid situation.  BUT we wanted to go.  Maybe he should not have to.

I have waited 30 years for this journey, this travel was my birthday present, we wanted to bring out the most and the most beautiful memories of these 3 days and I decided that I will enjoy every minute… But overall unfortunately I am we are disappointed.

title: Excellent Celebration Stay
text:
We booked to celebrate our Anniversary just after New Year's.
  When we arrived at noon we were immediately checked in and given an upgrade to a Central Park view high floor room.  Everything in the room (and the hotel) was sparkling clean.
After returning from lunch we found champagne & strawberries waiting for us!
The executive lounge was open for beverages (6am-2pm)  and for buffet breakfast in the morning (9-11am).  jAn excellent selection of breakfast foods.
Security was evident - made us feel very comfortable. 
The location made it great to walk to Central Park, visit Rockefeller Center (the tree was still up, Time Warner center & Lincoln Center.   If only the Broadway shows we wanted to see were running, it would have been even better ..... but hopefully next time we stay.   And we will definitely be staying again.
 
Overall a 10+ experience - from correspondence to check in to departure.

title: Beautiful main areas, lovely minimalist room, great views
text: Room was pleasantly minimalist and had excellent views of Central Park. Large glass shower was without fault and extremely enjoyable. Pared back, minimalist room was a nice contrast to a maximalist and sumptuous lobby. Staff were generally friendly but when trying to communicate about things like spa services, I often could not get anyone on the phone, and eventually gave up. F&B credit was nice to spend on Champagne by the glass, but otherwise restaurant was nothing to write home about. Breakfast options a la carte were fine, but the buffet exceeded expectations the next day — who knew a hotel buffet could be nice? All in all, the price tag was worth it for park views, but I wouldn't bother with a standard room.

title: Perfect Holiday Stay
text: Excellent stay. Pretty quiet during the pandemic. The hotel lobby was decorated for Christmas and our room had a view of Central Park. There was even snow on Christmas eve morning! Caesar at the front desk was very nice and welcoming. The Executive Lounge is fantastic for breakfast - as nice as any breakfast buffets in Europe.

title: Location, Friendly staffs, Great service - 4.5/5 rating due to poor Wi-Fi connection
text:
Overall, it was a great experience staying at the JW M Essex House in NYC!   We have been to NYC many times an always trying new hotels throughout Manhattan & Brooklyn.  

Reason why it's 4.5 due to shortage of bathroom amenities and lack of responses with advance request via Mobile App.  We had to contact housekeeping upon checking due to advance request did not happen.  Staffs quickly delivered the requested items.  Throughout the stay, hotel did not have body wash due to supply shortage.  We also did not have any view even with advance booking and a Titanium Lifetime member.  I also have suite nights upgrades and did not happen.  I understand the holiday season, so this is a slim to none unless you pay full price for the room upfront.

Now that the negative feedback is done, the positives are location, staff, services and decoration.

- Location: definitely convenience of walking to key attractions, shopping, restaurants, museums.  Of course, taking the subway is only a 5min walk to Columbus circle and other stations nearby.  10min Walking over to 5th Ave to experience the Xmas window decoration was nice!

- Staffs & services: Genuinely friendly, especially upon check-in.  Front desk staff took the time to acknowledge and provide explanations of why my suite upgrade request could not be accommodated along with the view of Central park rooms.  Housekeeping and the rest of the staffs are also friendly with a smile!   Room is well maintained, clean upon check-in.  

- Restaurant:  It's odd the hotel restaurant does not open to serve foods/dinner before 5pm.  You could order drinks all you want but not foods until after 5pm for dinner.  We found out due to one night we wanted to eat at the hotel restaurant due to Broadway show time.  We ended up rushing to a nearby restaurant we had dinner the night before for a quick bite before heading to the show we booked that evening.  Services is great but it does get very busy pretty much every night.  We always stop by for a drink or two and desserts after coming back from a show or sightseeing around town.  Nice way to "chillax".. before calling it a night.

- Execs lounge: Only open for buffets breakfast and not in the afternoon for happy hours or Hors d 'Oeuvres due to COVIDS.  Good foods and services with a smile.  Love the option of drip coffee and separate coffee machines for express, cappuccino, etc.  Lots of options including fruits and healthy options to choose from so you do not have to repeat eggs with bacons or sausages every morning.

- Room:  Clean, comfortable beds, no noises could be heard from adjacent rooms or above which is wonderful for a good night sleep/rest!   

- Wi-Fi:  The room we stayed in has practically no or very poor Wi-Fi connection!  We did contact staff with the problem but could not resolve.  You have to stand near the entry or the hallway in front of the bathroom to good connectivity.  When sitting on the beds, signal is in and out.  The rest of the time, we ended using cell phone service provide signal to check emails or travel itinerary.  I hope this issue could be resolved in the future.  I understand some rooms will have this issue, no matter which hotel and we happen to get this room on this trip.

title: Disappointing
text:
Disappointing. I have 110 Marriott nights this year and around 900 for my lifetime.  I am a Titanium elite member.

In all that time as a Titanium elite member, I never had to pay for an upgrade when a suite was available. However, the JW Marriott Essex house charged me $375 a night for my upgrade. I was only there one night and the suite was available. In addition, it was one of the lowest level suites they have. Not even a big one. 

To top it off, there was food in the small mini fridge that obviously had been there for a long time as there was mold on it. In addition, one of the remotes did not work and the channel that had a football game on that I wanted to watch kept going in and out. 

We have always stayed at the Marriott Marquis in Times Square and they always accommodated us. However, they were sold out. 

The JW Marriott Essex house is not a place for Marriott Bonvoy elite members, as the definitely do not recognize your loyalty.

title: Birthday treat for my friend
text:
It was very exceptional birthday treat for my friend 
Well appointed room given to us an upgrade to a sweeping view of millionaire’s row skyscrapers . Thank you Yanera for your great assistance. 👍🏼Thank you to Laura Burton and Madeline Vargas. Carmen was there, very pleasant and courteous 💖 so grateful for everything, Thank you Mr Daniel and Ms D. ( Danuskha) for a perfect  birthday treat ( Prosecco with cheese board) so delicious!! Loved the suite with balcony. Huge room, big bathroom , nice windows and furnishings. Very clean and tidy. Can’t wait to stay here again. As I have been saying. JW Essex House is my home away from home 🏠 
I have to experience on this property for the New  year Eve fireworks display 🥰
Thank you to the courteous staff in the Executive club lounge like Anna , Rasheid and especially to smiling Charly 😍 and of course to my favorite in house restaurant, The Southgate, Ms D , Iqbal ( server ) famous Ms D , Marcela, ever accommodating and the new manager Mr Daniel 👍🏼👍🏼 Thank you all for your impeccable hospitality 💕

title: Good Location
text: We had a nice stay at this property.  The location is great, right across the street from Central Park.  The room was fine.  My only complaint is that the bathroom had mould around the tub.  The bed was comfortable, and the space wasn't bad considering it is NYC.  We had a nice breakfast in their restaurant on the first morning and there were great coffee shops just around the corner.

title: Poor showing, Marriott
text: This property is weak for the JW Marriott portfolio.  I don’t often post negative reviews, but i am extremely disappointed with the facilities and service granted for a site that costs 80k points per night.  As a Titanium Elite member, I received not only not preferential treatment to a suite but received a room with an interior courtyard view facing directly onto another building AND the room is….not even close to JW standards.  And as a complaint directly to Marriott: what is the point of offering suite night awards when you can never redeem them??? I booked this 2 night stay 2 months ago and was not even recognized with anything for my status upon check-in.  I’m posting photos of the room so you can see for yourself.  Shame on you Marriott and this JW property for treating loyal customer like crap.

title: Amazing stay at the JW
text: This place has it it all, the view to Central Park is just amazing but what really made my stay perfect was the staff. Cintia was just amazing, she even sent an amenity to my room for an special occasion. I’ll definitely come back and recommend this place.

title: Great Hotel/Room, Poor Overall Experience
text:
I have mixed feelings about this hotel and my overall experience. 

—- The hotel and room —-

The hotel is very well situated across the road from Central Park and has great access to subway lines. The hotel itself is beautiful and is what you would expect of an older NYC hotel. 

Our room (the Manhattan Suite #3310) was beautiful. At approx 700 square feet, we had plenty of room. The room was clean and the bed was super comfortable. The bathroom was well appointed, however the shower was a little on the small side - but had great water pressure! The bathroom amenities were also great. 

The room did not have a mini bar or coffee making facilities - something I’d expect from a five star hotel. Maybe it is a covid thing - not sure, but a little annoying. You can always call room service for anything you need, just be prepared to pay for it.

We also had access to the Executive Lounge during our stay. We visited it once during the day and it was a little disappointing. There was only coffee/tea on offer and everything else was out of stock. 

The staff we encountered during our actual stay were helpful and friendly. 

—- The experience —-

We had booked a one night stay via the Marriott Website. My husband is a Platinum Elite with Bonvoy (Marriott’s loyalty program).

We booked a Central Park View Room (King) - for our stay, this room was charged to us at just over $1000 USD (including taxes). 

After booking we decided to use one of our Suite Nite Awards to see if we could get an upgrade to a Junior Suite . This was honored pretty quickly by the hotel and we got upgraded to the Junior Suite (King), 

Upon confirmation of the upgrade, I messaged the hotel to request a 4pm checkout. According to the Marriott Bonvoy app, Platinum Elite are Guaranteed a 4pm late checkout (see picture from Bonvoy app). The person I was chatting too via the Bonvoy app (at the hotel) told me that we could have a 2pm as late check outs were not Guaranteed - even though their own app tells me it is! After a discussion I simply asked them to leave a note on file that we’d like to chat with a manager during checking. 

The person I was speaking to (a manager apparently) was not very professional nor helpful. 

We’ve been with Bonvoy for years and their program really doesn’t deliver on the benefits they advertise and after spending $1000 per night for this room, I was not about to let it go! I do not like having to beg to get the advertised benefits, the hotels should know what each member is entitled to and deliver on it without question. If hotels have an issue with it, they need to take it up with corporate. 

After giving them a bad review on Facebook, we were quickly contacted and given a 4pm checkout. Upon checking our booking we noticed that we had been further upgraded to the Manhattan suite - I’m guessing they had already sold the Junior Suite to another customer on the day we were checking out. We also got an email from the hotel advising us that whilst late checkouts are not Guaranteed, they would honor it this time.

The hotel also included a web link to the benefits of Bonvoy by tier. Whilst every tier did state “*subject to availability), it did not state this for the Platinum Elite group and the data on this website differs from that in their own app. Their attempt to prove a point failed (see attached). I’m going to take a guess that the genius responsible for their websites/app had missed the “*subject to availability) note on the Platinum Elite section. 

I did point this out to the hotel, but it seems they were not interested, rather they will have to constantly deal with issues like this. 

I’m constantly disappointed by Marriott hotels and their Bonvoy program. The Bonvoy program was clearly created by a marketing team with zero ability to consult with hotels. This entire experience was the last straw for us - we’ve now decided to ditch the program and focus on AirBNB or a status match with IHG or Hilton. 

So to sum up, hotel and room would have received a 5/5 rating, the experience should receive a 1/5.

title: Not recommended
text:
One of the worst 5* properties I ever stayed in (in this price range, starting at 650 USD / night at nov/dec 2021). 

Not sure where to start, but we checked in as Marriott Titanium Elite Member and the status was not recognized at all - you have to beg for your benefits. There is alot of staff in the lobby, but noone really cares to help. We were here with a stroller for 5 nights, and not helped at all with anything. Noone opened the door for us to get in or out, noone helped with our luggaged as we arrived (only after asking). We had to move our room after 2 nights (upon our request), that worked, however noone asked if we need help to move the luggage. Remember this is a 5* luxury property (at least it claims to be).

Two other big disadvantages for us for the sleep:

- the windows are very thin, no isolation at all, you hear every car from outside (we hat our second room below level 10)
- if you are used to sleep in dark rooms, you won't be able to sleep here - there's no way to get the room "dark" at all since the curtain doesn't match the windows

And there are so many small details to add..:

- no drinking glasses in the room (only two plastic cups)
- no bathrobe
- no minibar nor fridge in the room
- the USB-Charger at the bed didn't work 
- the battery of the TV-Remote control was empty
- the executive lounge has a very small seating-area, you will sit very close eachother and it's so crowded (even during Covid-19)
- the gym/fitness area is very small, the weight-area can be occupied with 2 people maximum

The good things..

- the location next to the central-park if you care about that
- the food itself (the executive lounge was able to use the buffet-breakfast of the restaurant) has a good choice/taste
- the marriott bed's/pillows

I would definitely not stay here again, as there's so many better choices in NYC. However, most of the things above could be fixed with better management/staff.

title: Toddler Playing with Broken Glass
text:
Stayed at the Essex from 11/17 to 11/21 in a Central Park View Suite.
The rating of 'poor stay' is simple. The Managers (Housekeeping and Front of the house) did not resolve an urgent matter that could have resulted in much more - Infant found broken glass, and no one cared to do anything about it.
Situation: My 15 month old son found broken glass on the floor of the room (grabbed it near a chair and threw it near me). Managers were told about the situation (all of them present at the lobby of the hotel on 11/17), apologized, and promised to clean the room again in 40 minutes when we would be away at dinner. When we came back the room was the same, but what was even more surprising was that we found a, even bigger, sharper piece of broken glass (thankfully before our son did). I called service immediately and when I spoke to the Manager, she said 'I remember you from earlier, you are saying the room was not cleaned? I am surprised because the Housekeeping manager was there when you let us know about the broken glass.) Given the time of day, my wife spent 10 minutes looking for more glass before we could put our son to bed. The manager let us know they would clean the room thoroughly next day in the morning, however, no one came to clean anything until noon. The manager threw some 'Bonvoy' points, which I did not even ask for or agree to, this to 'fix' the situation.
I would not recommend this hotel for a family stay. As far as I can see, this is used mainly by business travelers. Service is weak and amenities overall are too compared to the price paid per night. Definitely will not go back to this hotel on my next trip to New York.

title: Located on Central Park
text: This is not your typical Marriott.  This is a majestic property fronting New York Central Park with glorious views of you occupy a room on the upper floors facing the park.  The hotel occupies one of the most prized positions in all of New York City.

title: Excellent Service & Location
text: We stayed in 2 rooms for a family trip. Cesar at the front desk was incredibly helpful in accommodating our needs and getting our stay off to an excellent start. Thank you Cesar! Everyone we encountered from Michael the bellman to housekeeping staff were all very helpful. Excellent service is what truly distinguishes the Essex House. We had adjoining rooms with partial park views. The concierge lounge is only available for Platinum members and only for breakfast but there are many great places to eat nearby. Morton Williams market is only 2 blocks away on 57th between 6th and 7th Ave and a good place to pick up water and snacks.

title: luxury hotel with outstanding service and beautiful view in a wonderful location
text: Upon arrival Ceaser warmly and expertly checked us in a few minutes early to a wonderful room with a view of Central Park, and then helped us extend our stay for an additional night, when we realized 1 night was just not long enough.  Ceaser was very capable of providing attention to my husband and I as he was identifying the right room for us, while pausing briefly to help a colleague with issues she was unable to resolve and required his expertise.  Our king room was small, but included all the necessities, and gave us the perfect quiet refuge to enjoy along with Carnegie Hall, Central Park and New York's wonderful restaurants.  The comfortable bed, extra pillows and fabulous large shower were much appreciated.  We enjoyed omelets, perfectly prepared potatoes and lots of hot delicious coffee for breakfast at the 1st floor restaurant.  Although rather expensive, breakfast was appropriately priced for a luxury hotel at this location and both service and quality were excellent.  The hostess kindly seated us by the window upon request and the Restaurant Manager stopped at the table to welcome us and ensure we were enjoying our meal. Covid safety protocols were graciously followed, so we felt comfortable dining.  The valet and concierge staff were extremely kind and helpful in every way from recommending restaurants to providing directions, to hailing a taxi for us at departure. We look forward to staying at the JW Marriott Essex House when we return to New York in the Spring.

title: Great location off Central Park!
text:
I recently booked a room at the JW Marriot Essex House for a special occasion - my dad's birthday. The rooms were expensive, particularly for the Park View, but the beautiful hotel, location, and historic architecture were all totally worth it. 

The rooms are not massive and aren't exactly the fanciest, but then again a spacious hotel room in New York is very VERY rare. They were clean, well put together and good enough for one night. 

My positive review, however, is in particular for the lovely hotel staff. The concierge Howard was extremely helpful, nice, and friendly. I called a couple days earlier to ask for a nice view on a higher floor and potentially a champagne bottle to be sent to the room. 

He was extremely honest and kind and set my parents with a room with the most perfect view of Central Park! I opted not to get the champagne due to the price, and we were actually surprise with the champagne, and a lovely hand drawn note delivered to the room!

title: Great location, nice accommodations
text:
For two nights in October, room 1222 at the JW Essex was home.  The location is a favorite being directly across from Central Park.  While this is my second stay at the property, neither time have I lucked into a room facing the park.  To be transparent, both of my stays were booked using Marriott points.  Anytime I book with points, the room is hardly ever the nicest they offer.  
By New York standards, room 1222 is a spacious King with nice closet space.  It is appointed with a desk/chair, chase and the counterpace in the bathroom is plenty for one person.  The shower is on the small size but worked for me.  The bed was comfortable.  They fulfilled my request for foam pillows as I find all Marriott properties pillows less than ideal but the foam provides a little better support.  The bathroom products were of good quality and plentiful.  Never did I need to request additional soaps, towels or such.  The robe and slippers were comfortable as well.  
The room faces a brick building so the view is nothing worth commenting on other than to say it’s private.  No worries of anyone seeing into your room.  I could look up and see sunshine but it would have been nice to enjoy a view, even of a street – if nothing more than to let a little light in.  I found it odd that there was no clock nor in-room coffee/tea.  I thought certain in-room amenities were standard for such a property.  There also is an empty space in the tv cabinet that seems to have once stored a mini-fridge.  However, there is a cut out in the bottom of the cabinet which makes it unusable for storage.  
While the room is near the elevator, I didn’t find there to be any issue with noise.  Even with weekend travelers, it was quiet.  While the elevators are on the small size, there are several of them, and I never had to wait more than a minute.  The executive lounge adjacent the lobby restaurant offered coffee, tea and breakfast options.  I only went down each morning for coffee and to grab a couple bottles of water.  It was a spacious lounge.  The coffee is Lavazza which is fairly good.  The tea was limited to a few Tazo selections.  It would have been nice to see a higher quality tea and a little more variety of flavors.  While I enjoy coffee in the morning, an evening cup of herbal tea would have been lovely.  I did not eat breakfast but the bagels looked delicious.  
The staff was pleasant.  Nothing to note, good nor bad.  The JW Essex is a historical hotel and I can say that at other historical hotels I have stayed, the staff was a little more personal.  
I would stay again at the JW Essex.  As mentioned, the location is lovely. The accommodations are nice.  There is nothing extraordinary about the property which I experienced but it is priced accordingly.

title: Great Hotel! Great Staff!
text: Front desk was very nice and checked us in quickly. Helped us with an issue before I had to ask. Room was nice, and good size. Excellent location right on Central Park. Restaurant had an excellent dinner. Hope to stay again soon, made for a fun weekend in nyc.

title: Not worth the price at all
text:
One of the worst hotels I've stayed in. They were running on what felt like skeletal staff, there was hardly anyone around and we were put in the smallest room which barely fit the travel cot we requested for our daughter to sleep in. There was no fridge in the room - we had to request one so I could store breast milk) - when it arrived it didn't actually fit in the cupboard designated for it so it had to be placed in under the desk so you could no longer sit at the desk. I asked guest services if it would be possible to have a kettle in the room so I c an prepare my daughter's food and was told that guest services was closed (its was 5pm) and that I could purchase a bottle warmer from Macy's as the hotel couldn't provide boiling water( the restaurant was also closed) and they don't have kettles 'to her knowledge'. After complaining about the terrible service and the tiny room for 2 adults and a baby we were upgraded to a suite by the lovely manager Alan. He was great and profusely apologised about our experience and was able to locate a bottle warmer for us. However, inspite of the lovely upgrade I hated the entire experience. The rooms felt dirty and weren't cleaned properly, the decor of the hotel as a whole but also the rooms was very dated and honestly for the price we paid ($750 for 2 nights) it was really not worth a penny at all!

In addition, the breakfast - a. JOKE! They trick you by telling you on arrival you have $30 towards extras at breakfast because we opted fro breakfast to be inclusive and I'll tell you now that $30 only covers a drink for 2 people. The buffet breakfast was vile and flies were all over the pastries, they had a selection of continental breakfast options but everything looked stale and not fresh - we went down fro breakfast at 8am and it opens at 6:30am. In the end we ordered from the menu at the restaurant and everything came out cold and tasted very below average. Sadly, I will never stay at this hotel again and considering its supposed to be such a well known hotel I was thoroughly disappointed. I will say that the few staff we encountered (there was barely anyone around it felt quite eery) were lovely and helpful - other than the teams who answer the phones.

title: Perfect location and excellent staff.
text: Had a wonderful recent stay with friends. Laura Burton went above and beyond to make it a special trip for us. All of the staff I encountered were friendly and helpful. I also appreciate that they are making efforts to getting the executive lounge back up to full service- the breakfast was nice. I enjoyed my time so much that I'm returning with my husband next week to celebrate our anniversary.

title: Do not stay! So overpriced. Terrible value.
text: DO NOT STAY! Rooms are basic and tiny. Not worth the extreme price. Do not trust hotel photos. Foyer is stunning but It’s a 2 star hotel at best once you go to the guest rooms. So disappointed in Marriott. Same price can get you a Hilton Conrad 1 block away! DO NOT BOOK IT

title: Fantastic time at JW - ahead of my wedding
text: My husband and I stayed at the JW during our wedding weekend in Sept, seperate rooms before the wedding and joint rooms after the wedding. We got upgraded - which I thought was extremely nice. My bridal suite was very comfortable for all the makeup and wedding preparation with bridesmaids. Everyone at the JW was so nice and accommodating - including allowing us take pictures at the lobby before heading out for the ceremony. Would stay again and recommend

title: BED BUGS - 6th Floor Room facing Central Park
text: I write this review after giving the JW Essex House more than 2 months to follow up on a serious incident I experienced while staying at this property. As the highest level of Marriott Loyalty status (Ambassador Elite) I am still dumbfounded by the Essex house’s lackluster dedication to customer service and health concerns. In June, I booked a stay at this property to celebrate my wife’s birthday. I had my Ambassador assist me with this booking in hopes of having the best possible stay. At arrival I was greeted by a lovely receptionist. Her name escapes me, but she was Filipino and was the only reason this review was given more than 1-star. Unfortunately, the rest of the stay was incredibly disappointing. Typically, with status I have access to the lounge, which was only partially true, at the Essex House. The first afternoon of arrival they “closed” the lounge for some unknown reason. When I inquired, no one had any answers. For all the reviews about how knowledgeable and helpful the staff that I’ve read about this property it could not have been further from the truth during my stay. Onto the most egregious and unbelievable experience was upon my return home the following day. Shortly after having arrived home I noticed my leg was itchy. After further investigation it appeared as though I had bug bites. The same was found on my wife’s legs as well. BED BUGS! I contacted the hotel promptly to notify them of this. During my phone conversation with the receptionist, I was told that the manager on duty was gone for the day and that a message would be left for that person when they return the following day. I emphasized on this call the importance of making sure that any other guests who might currently be in our same room be notified. I was told the manager would contact me the following day. To my surprise two days had passed before, I had to follow up. ME! The hotel guests who had bites on OUR legs had to escalate the concern with A SECOND phone call. The hotel then tried connecting me with the manager. Her name is Laura B. Laura shared with me that other hotel guests were staying in our room and that they could not enter to conduct a bedbug inspection until they checked-out. Once they did, she would have their “specialist” come in to provide an assessment and follow up with me regarding the findings. Guess what happened next? NOTHING. No follow, yet again. Quite the showing from management here so far, right? Anyhow, after I called to personally follow up again because our legs were still itching, I finally hear back. I was told that the inspection found no bedbugs, but the official report could not be shared with me. Instead, Laura offered to open a case and pass me onto Lourdes M and Carlos M. After multiple email exchanges and scheduled call times to discuss – no one ever followed up. Shocking? Not really. As previously stated, this lack of concern and follow up doesn’t quite live up to the JW name most of us have come accustomed to. Bottom line - do not stay at this hotel. You’ve been warned - if you get bedbug bites during your stay at the JW Essex House no one will care. Your pleas to be a responsible citizen ,so that other don’t experience the same, will go unheard.

title: Hanan room 529
text: Though I am staying for a long period, the services given are not as expected from 5 stars hotel. There is no water, no coffee maker in the room and their excuse is due to COVID 19, although the next door hotels like Ritz they allocate coffee maker, bottles of water! It’s gusts job to bring the water bottles everyday from the reception!  The bathroom is so dirty and the bathroom sink is blocked. When I called service line, they were unable to help and they did not answer my calls!!  Hotel deserves a 3 star max.👎

title: More a self service apt than an iconic 5 star hotel
text: This place feels like a self service apt than an iconic 5 star hotel.  There is no water, no kettle/coffee maker in the room.  We had  to pick up water bottles everyday from the reception.   After repeatedly asking for a kettle,  they brought one but it was disgusting so I had to ask for hot water daily.   If you don’t pay for a high floor Central Park view room, the chance of them giving you a generous upgrade is close to zero.  They made it clear to us that they get a lot of ambassadors and titanium members, and there is only limited rooms for Marriott status upgrade.  So work your totem pole.  I would recommend bring your money and status else where,  you might get a much better view room.   One of the managers was nice enough to give us one category upgrade for titanium membership,  the family suite was comfy in terms of the size, nothing luxurious. But  seriously with no view, there is no point of staying in this location unless you think you are in love w the Central Park.  The good restaurants and interesting scenes are mostly downtown.   Lastly, the executive lounge is a joke, no window, the free breakfast is a 3 star max, not even a glass cup for your cappuccino.  You have to pay to sit in their Southgate restaurant for the same breakfast.    The only worthy pic of the hotel is the entrance flower bouquet and the chandelier hallway,  there is no other interesting common  area to enjoy yourself which is very much a design mistake.   If you are used to Marriott JW Asian and Middle Eastern standards or even European 5 star standards, this hotel apart from its iconic status and location deserves a 3.5 star max.  Of course they attribute the lack of service to Covid.  The employees are overworked, often they mentioned they had to do 2-3 people’s jobs for the pay of one due to lack of workers.   I feel for you, but if you are charging the rate you are charging, your clients expect a certain level of service.

title: Small Room
text: Small room compared to other JW's we have stayed at, service was slow and check-in was delayed. Our extra towels weren't in the room per our profile. Great location, but smells like horse poop because all the horses line up across the street.

title: What a DUMP
text: 1st room they give us has water running down the wall and the rug smelt like crap 2nd room was almost 90 when we went in turned ac down to 60 and after 30 mins dropped down to85. No third chance so we checked out and they made us wait over 45 mins to return our car AVOID THIS PLACE

title: Dated and Terrible Security Protocol.
text:
Marriott Titanium. 

In NYC for a gallery opening and decided to stay at the JW and booked a suite.  

Pros:
- Can't beat the location. 
- Suite was big. 

Cons:
- Trying to talk to the front desk before arrival was one of the hardest I ever had to do.  I called to add my wife's name to the reservation as she was flying in earlier and every time I called to talk to a front desk rep to do so, was told by the operator that front desk agents were too busy to talk to me and that they would do it for me.  Fine, but when I called a week before our stay her name was not on the reservation.  Again, the operator told me I could not talk to the front desk and said she would do it for me.  Called the night before check to verify and it was still not on the reservation and was still told that I couldn't talk to the front desk.  
- Dated.  The rooms look like a Courtyard which would be fine if we were staying at a Courtyard.  
- Security is a joke and needs to be fixed immediately.  My sister in law met us at the hotel one night.  Unbeknownst to us, she left behind a personal item and went back to the hotel to retrieve it while we weren't there.  She shared with us that she told the front desk that she needed to get in the room and the agent let her in without checking any ID or calling us and had a security guard escort her to the room.  The security guard then opened our room and walked away.  Isn't this security 101 that you don't do this?  Failure on the highest levels. 

I'm not going to slam the hotel with all the COVID precautions they have in place, but good God, the hotel can't execute the basics when it comes to making guests feel welcome and safe.  

Maybe our stay was the exception, but we won't be back to see if it was.

title: Great Location and Concierge Service
text: At Central Park and walking distance to Times Square. We got very personal front desk service, and though it was before check-in time we were able to get a room, which was very helpful.  When we checked in the first thing I did was go to the Concierge (David O maybe; wish I could remember his name) and he was extremely helpful with planning our activities for the day, the the next day when we were going to the Bronx Stairs and the Jersey shore. Hotel is very pricey and valet parking is $95 (but worth it to me since I had never driven in Manhattan before). There were no dinner options went we went in July.

title: not worth the price
text: go to this hotel if u want a mediocre experience, i’ve been to other hotels 1/8th of the price yet the same quality, i ordered another roll up bed for my room due to us having more people than we thought, i wait 2 hours for a bed. 😐. the tvs were slow, and i know i’m just complaining, it’s a good hotel just nothing worth the price

title: Do not stay here!
text:
We stayed at this hotel in January and had a great stay. This July was horrendous. Pre pandemic we traveled extensively. Now, wanting to dip a toe into the travel scene again, we have booked a few trips. We still do have our Marriott platinum status. 
I can’t begin to describe the horrible nature of our recent stay at this hotel. We were given a room after a long flight that had been flooded the night before. There were four intense hot blowers in the room blowing hot air everywhere, and yet we were given this room. We went to the front desk they gave us another room. This room was like an icebox box - literally. The temperature would not go above 63°. We finally had the engineer come, and he said oh well the heat is off in the hotel. Nothing I can do. Finally our third room was acceptable but we had other problems. There was no staff for the front desk, with one person and 30 people trying to check in. No room service. The restaurant was open limited hours with limited food. Our problem was just a total lack of personnel or any interest in making our stay even minimally acceptable.  I won’t even mention all the details about the valet that did not deliver our car for 45 minutes past the requested time and we requested it the night before. Needless to say, our drive to Newark airport was filled with anxiety due to their lack of competency.  
Run run run away!!  Do not stay here!

title: Worst five star hotel experience ever, bar none
text:
For a five star hotel that charges on average $650/night this was by far the worst experience I have ever had, bar none. Upon arrival, the hotel had no bellman to help with luggage.

Also this alleged five star hotel has almost no service. No room services, no fridge in room, not even a tea kettle. In addition the front desk refuses to send water to the room. Complimentary water at 8 ounces a bottle can only be taken from the front desk by oneself.

On top of the lack of service, there is the atrocious attitude of service. Without actually saying “No, no, f*ck off”, the entire hotel staff have done an exceptional job of conveying that exact message.

In terms of the room, I understand the premium in New York, but even then the room is small and mediocrely furnished. I can hardly imagine anyone who has stayed here ever wanting to come back unless he has a glutton for punishment. 

I find this establishment to be shameful and terribly inadequate!

title: Not up to par for a five star hotel
text: We did not catch this hotel and its staff at their best. We were there Memorial Day weekend and mask wearing was still required inside the hotel. The hotel restaurant was closed. This hotel has a great view of Central Park from almost any floor. We, unfortunately, were using Marriott points and had a view of the inner shaft. If you stay here, the rooms are expensive to begin with. You should pay a bit extra and to have a view of the park. The service was lackluster. When we arrived at the front door, there was no one to take our car or bags. We went inside to check in and waited about 30 minutes total for a valet to take our keys. My wife and I wanted to attend mass our first morning there at a nearby RC church. The lady behind the front desk was very cheery but she spent at least 10 minutes to find a church. She handed us a sheet of paper that had the name and address of the church but not the mass times. She was clearly new and not well trained. The room was spacious for New York and had the look of faded luxury. There was a marble bath but the grout was missing between some of the marble on the floor. A chaise lounge was very worn with material missing on a section of the piping. There was a covid breakfast at no additional charge. The breakfast selections were limited by covid restrictions, but there was a good selection of fruit, cereals and pastries. The coffee was self service with a multi-functional machine to dispense espresso, cappuccino, etc. While sipping our cappuccinos, we missed the barista made brew we are used to almost anywhere in France and Italy and at most upscale hotels in America. This hotel is convenient to the major museums of NYC and Fifth Ave shopping. We chose the hotel because it was close to our daughters new apartment.

title: Amazing stay in our beautiful suite
text:
Thank you very much to  Laura Burton 🌺( Resident Manager) of JW Essex House in Central Park New York City and Madeline Vargas, Executive Assistant 🌸 it was an amazing stay at our beautiful suite . The upgrade was very much appreciated 💖
Bellman Mr Q was very helpful and courteous 👌 Felix at the reception was professional.
It’s nice to meet Madeline . Great conversation 👍🏼 This property always exceeded my expectations . They followed Covid protocol seriously, that’s for the safety of everyone 👌
They offered free coffee and drinks , fresh fruits and energy bars  , yogurt and all . Easy grab and go for all the guest at their Club Lounge. That’s very generous gesture from JW Essex House. Unfortunately, my favorite restaurant in house ( Southgate) is still closed 🥲 although there’s plenty of restaurants nearby, walking distance to the Columbus circle. Getting around to the Central Park is few blocks away . I enjoyed my short stay . My family enjoyed it more 😍 I loved going around few blocks shopping 🛍 to Nordstrom 💖
Even is walkable, going to 5th Avenue and to the Rockefeller center and St Patrick’s cathedral. But the most gracious reception I ever met was Hanna , very sweet and accommodating. She reminded me of Jasmine.💖 Hopefully the F and B will be back in service soon 🙏 I can’t wait to be back here again and again, my home away from home. The customer service here is exceptional!!! I had experienced great memories in this iconic place. I really can’t say thank you enough to every staff I met here 🙏💝👌 I truly highly recommend this hotel for comfort and satisfaction!!! Thank you!!!

title: Staff does their best despite the circumstances.
text: Was upgraded to a great view of CP so added a point.  Added another point because the staff was very friendly.  If you're a regular Marriott property during the pandemic and charging $125/nt, then I really don't expect anything more than a clean room.  But if you are a JM Marriott and charging $500+ per night then I expect a nicer property and full amenities.  JMM's Essex House is a "tired" looking property, and for this brand to not have any restaurant or room service is unacceptable in my scoring.

title: Amazing staff and great Location
text:
Being across the street from Central Park is great, but this hotel staff truly made this visit memorable for my son. They have him toys upon arrival, we’re very kind and super attentive to us..

Things are limited with Covid-19 so the lounge for elite members doesn’t offer a real breakfast.I think more could be done here perhaps to offer delivered eggs or something upon request...

However, overall would come back here with my family again. Having lived in New York it was great being back as a tourist and staying here. Thanks Essex House!

title: Excellent Service, Perfect Location
text: My husband and I are New Yorkers (well, we moved abroad in 2018 but we were raised there) and we could not recommend this hotel enough to anyone in need of a short or long stay in the city. During the pandemic, we have stayed at the Bryant Park Hotel, Aloft, Hilton Millennium, and JW Marriott Essex House is hands down the most comfortable, safe and beautiful place to stay. Not only is it perfectly located on Central Park South so you can get all the exercise and fresh air you need every day, but you are also a block or 2 from Columbus Circle where all the shops are open and the best Whole Foods I’ve ever been to is located downstairs. We were able to get groceries for our son any time because WF is open early and closes late. If the endless cold and hot selection at WF is not enough for you, we were able to order anything we craved from DoorDash and UberEats AND the hotel staff would bring our orders to our room. Housekeeping was available every day until 2:30pm but we didn’t bother because our suite was provided with enough amenities and towels from the first day. I have Marriott status so we were upgraded to a junior suite from the King room I had booked and we were given a beautiful room (no view, but a girl can’t get everything she wants in Manhattan all the time) but we needed a bathtub for our baby and the room was huge but we needed to work so some division of space was preferable while our baby napped and played during the day. The staff was incredibly responsive and moved us to another suite immediately. Although the restaurant and other facilities was closed, there was always someone at reception and a bellman/security at the front doors to help in whatever way they could. The hotel has a very convenient back entrance on 58th Street as well. Tons of COVID testing sites are around the hotel which was appreciated since we needed to get PCR and rapid tests to return to Europe, and the hotel staff printed out all our necessary documents we may need for our flight. The manager also approved a late checkout for us since our departing flight was at 8pm from JFK and so we were able to have our baby nap in our room and have sufficient time to pack up and tidy up before calling a Lyft. Drop off and pick up is also very convenient at this location because Centra Park South has so many lanes unlike most other NYC blocks. We benefited from very mild weather so we meandered through Central Park to feed the ducks, watch ice skaters and even walked up to the Museum of Natural History on 80th St which was open to the public by reservation. For the more touristy people, Rockefeller Center and Time Square are a short walk away.  The Apple Store is a block away as is the Plaza where I used to enjoy a fancy afternoon tea. Lincoln Center is also very close but closed because of COVID and for renovations. Our room provided a much needed respite and was very quiet and came with 2 big TVs so we were able to play YouTube kids videos on one while I watched HBO on the other! Lavazza coffee, bottled water, fresh fruit and other snacks like KIND bars were provided every morning until 11am and was much appreciated for us jetlagged travelers! The hotel is gorgeous and incredibly clean and well kept so we enjoyed our stay thoroughly. We have stayed at the JW Marriott in Hong Kong so it was nice to see some familiarity/consistency like in the Aromatherapy bathroom products. On our second day, the hotel staff gave our baby a puzzle and little stuffed animals which he absolutely loved, so thank you again! I would recommend booking this hotel before prices go up again once borders open up and tourists flood back into NYC!

title: What a disappointing experience...
text:
Spent four days in NYC. Decided to spend one night at the JW Marriott and then extend if I liked it. After one day I was already packing my bags.

I have spent 30-40  nights / year in Marriott hotels (Platinium status) over the last 5 years and this was the worst experience I had.

Cons
* Very understaffed and it feels like 10% of the staff is doing 90% of the work.
* Unpleasant room service on the phone
* At 12:15pm, someone was banging on my door aggressively to ask me to check out
* Pricey rate ~ 450$/night esp. during covid
* Got a super noisy room next to the outdoor ventilation/heating(?) system with no view
* Rooms are quite small

Pros
* Location
* The lobby is beautiful

If you are looking for a premium experience next to Central Park, the Ritz Carlton is amazing even though it is closed temporarily.  I wanted to try the JW Marriott but that was a mistake.

title: Always AMAZING!
text:
I have stayed at the JW Marriott 3 times in the past 3 months and this time for 6 days. I continue to come back because the staff is helpful, friendly and approachable, the premises are impeccably clean and neat, the rooms are spacious and comfortable and they always recognize my lifetime Marriott platinum status with upgrades and offers. All of this is in addition to the most convenient location across from Central Park and 1 block from 5th Avenue. In a 15 minute stroll, I can get anywhere in Manhattan by turning a corner or two. This place has been a NYC staple for over 20 years and they’ve still got it! 

On this trip- I was upgrade from an Essex king to a Junior Suite (pics below).

title: Overall, OK stay but could use more update to stay competitive.
text:
Pretty good hotel if you have the right opportunity/occasion to stay. 

Pro: beautiful hotel. feel of lux NYC apt, location is excellent for central park stroll, times sq (if you are into that), interior equally as lux

con: outdated.. smart tv is really slow (never seen netflix lag this much), bathtub water was brown when you fully open the faucet. service: hard to put it into words but it felt oddly uncomfortable. the front desk was courteous, but I didn't quite like the way manager (?) was sitting by the corner monitoring. maybe it's covid precaution... also puzzled as to why gym is not on the top floor with central park view. Maybe that's newer trend.

title: A bit dated and the staff not too helpful.
text:
We stayed here for one night.  Due to COVID-19 the whole place felt deserted. Although my booking was under Marriott's platinum membership even then the lady did not give us a park view room, instead a back room with no view whatsoever. 

I think this might be the only hotel in NYC that has muslim showers in its bathrooms. Clean, comfortable, I just wish the service would have been better.

title: Terrible from check in to check out
text:
My husband and I booked a night here at the JW Marriott Essex House, as our go to Marriott hotels, the St Regis and Ritz Carlton are currently closed. We drove our car to the hotel and valeted it. While we reside in NYC, I am initially from the Midwest, and therefore, my photo ID reflects that. The hotel associate asked me for the airport paperwork that must be filled out when visiting NY and I told her that I live in NY and therefore do not have paperwork. She accepted my response and promptly checked us in and even gave us late check out at 1 PM. We then rode up the elevator to our room. We walked into our room and found the bed covered in about 50 throw pillows and numerous stacked ice buckets and trays piled on the desk. I called down to the front desk to ask for a room change, as it seemed that we were accidentally given a room used for storage. An associate met us at our room with a new key for a new room on the same floor. I was secretly hoping for an upgrade at this point since the initial room was not acceptable. We were shown to our new room which was the same size as the first one. We quickly unpacked a few things and ordered an Uber to go to our dinner reservation in the Financial District. As we waited for the elevator to arrive, the same hotel associate reappeared and to our surprise, he said that his manager had approved an upgrade for us (we had not expressed our interest in one) to make up for their mistake with our first room. We were already running late to our dinner reservation so we accepted the upgrade as well as his offer to move our belongings to the new room. 
The new room was slightly larger and had a gorgeous view of Central Park. However, I did find the room to be rather outdated in its design. Additionally, the bathroom was outfitted with a bathtub/shower combo and the bathtub was very high. At seven months pregnant, it was difficult for me to step in and out of the bathtub. There was no fan in the bathroom, resulting in the bathroom getting rather foggy and steamy when showering.
The TV responded quite slowly to the remote and did not have such a great selection of channels. 
Lastly, throughout the night we were able to hear noise from the street below and it disturbed our sleep.
When it was time to check out the following day, the hotel associate at the front desk offered to email me the receipt for our stay. Once in the car and on our way, I opened the email and found that we were charged a $382 room change charge as well as $95 oversized car valet charge (the car in question is a 2016 Honda Pilot). I immediately called the front desk to dispute the room change charge and after much back and forth they agreed to refund the $382. 
From all the glitches and lack of professionalism displayed by this hotel, I would not return or recommend this hotel to anyone. I sincerely hope that the category 8 Marriott hotels reopen soon.

title: Amazing location, wonderful staff
text: If you want a nice hotel with an amazing location, the Essex House is hard to beat.  So close to Central Park.  Easy cab ride just about anywhere in Manhattan.  The lobby staff were so friendly -- they even gave my daughter a Marriott stocking cap to help with the very windy weather that day.  Don't expect fancy rooms -- the rooms are nice and clean, but not fancy.  Overall, it was a very good stay.  I would definitely stay here again.

title: Nice size rooms for NYC
text: Stayed here one night for work. Very comfortable bed, was happy with the size of the room and the bathroom was nice too. No view, just looked at a wall, but otherwise the room was great. Very clean, friendly staff and security. The lounge was closed due to pandemic, but otherwise stay was great.

title: Not What I Expected
text: When you arrive at the JW Essex Marriott it is unclear where the valet wants you to park. There were many cars ahead parked alongside the hotel so I parked behind them only to see another hotel guest cut into a bunch of parked cars and get service before me. I continued to look for Valet workers but they were no where to be seen. Then it took a long time to check in but NOT due to other guests. There was only ONE person at the front desk and she had left her station to get cash for the ONLY hotel guest in front of me. When I booked the 2 rooms here I made a point to let the Front Desk know I wanted rooms close to each other but instead I got rooms on DIFFERENT floors.
